Unfortunately, this macro file is no longer supported by the current version of PhotoDemon.
In version 6.0, PhotoDemon macro files were redesigned to support new features, improve performance, and solve some long-standing reliability issues. Unfortunately, this means that macros recorded prior to version 6.0 are no longer compatible. You will need to re-record these macros from scratch.
(Note that any old macro files will still work in old versions of PhotoDemon, if you absolutely need to access them.)

There is not enough memory available to continue this operation. Please free up system memory (RAM) by shutting down unneeded programs - especially your web browser, if it is open - then try the action again.

Unfortunately, this image file appears to be invalid. This can happen if a file does not contain image data, or if it contains image data in an unsupported format.
- If you downloaded this image from the Internet, the download may have terminated prematurely. Please try downloading the image again.
- If this image file came from a digital camera, scanner, or other image editing program, it's possible that PhotoDemon simply doesn't understand this particular file format. Please save the image in a generic format (such as JPEG or PNG), then reload it.

The specified file could not be located. If it was located on removable media, please re-insert the proper floppy disk, CD, or portable drive. If the file is not located on portable media, make sure that: 1) the file hasn't been deleted, and... 2) the file location provided to PhotoDemon is correct.

PhotoDemon has experienced an error. Details on the problem include:
Error number %1 Description: %2
%3

Thank you for submitting a bug report. To make sure your bug is addressed as quickly as possible, PhotoDemon needs you to answer one more question.
Do you have a GitHub account? (If you have no idea what this means, answer "No".)

PhotoDemon has automatically opened a GitHub bug report webpage for you. In the Title box, please enter the following error number with a short description of the problem: %1
Any additional details you can provide in the large text box, including the steps that led up to this error, will help it get fixed as quickly as possible.
When finished, click the Submit New Issue button. Thank you!

PhotoDemon has automatically opened a bug report webpage for you. In the Comment box, please describe the steps that led to this error.
Also in that box, please include the following error number: %1
When finished, click the Submit button. Thank you!

Disclaimer: all hardware acceleration data is provided by the operating system. It specifically represents GDI acceleration, which is independent from DirectX and OpenGL. OS version and desktop mode also affect support capabilities. For best results, please run PhotoDemon on Windows 7 or 8, on an Aero-enabled desktop.
For more information on GDI hardware acceleration, visit http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ff729480

I understand the risks of running PhotoDemon in the IDE
Do not display this warning again
You are running PhotoDemon inside the Visual Basic IDE. This is not recommended.

Please compile PhotoDemon before using it. Many features that rely on subclassing are disabled in the IDE, but some - such as custom command buttons - cannot be disabled without severely impacting the program's functionality. As such, you may experience IDE instability and crashes, especially if you close the program using the IDE's Stop button.
Additionally, like all other photo editors, PhotoDemon relies heavily on multidimensional arrays. Array performance is severely degraded in the IDE, so some functions may perform very slowly.
If you insist on running PhotoDemon in the IDE, please do not submit bugs regarding IDE crashes or freezes. PhotoDemon's developers can only address issues and bugs that affect the compiled .exe.

Step 1: select the photo editing action(s) to apply to each image
Are you sure you want to cancel the current batch process?

If you exit now, your batch list (the list of images to be processed) will be lost. By saving your list, you can easily resume this batch operation at a later date.
Would you like to save your batch list before exiting?
You have already created a list of images for processing. The list of images inside this file will be appended to the bottom of your current list.
This is not a valid list of images. Please try a different file.
You have requested that a macro be applied to each image, but no macro file has been selected. Please select a valid macro file.
You have not selected any images to process! Please place one or more images in the batch list (at the bottom of the screen) before moving to the next step.
PhotoDemon cannot access the requested output folder. Please select a non-system, unrestricted folder for the batch process.
Welcome to PhotoDemon's batch wizard. This tool can be used to edit multiple images at once, in what is called a "batch process".
Start by selecting the photo editing action(s) you want to apply. If multiple actions are selected, they will be applied in the order they appear on this page.

Note: a "macro" is simply a list of photo editing actions. It can include any adjustment, filter, or effect in the main program. You can create a new macro by using the "Tools -> Macros -> Record new macro" menu in the main PhotoDemon window.
In the next step, you will select the images you want to process.
Step 2: prepare the batch list (the list of images to be processed)
You can add files to the batch list in several ways
1) The folder and file lists at the top of this page. Use the "Add selected image(s) to batch list" button to move images to the batch list, or use the right mouse button to drag-and-drop images.
2) The "Add images using Open Image dialog..." button.
3) Drag-and-drop files directly onto the batch list from Windows Explorer or your desktop.
Each of these methods supports use of the Ctrl and Shift keys to select multiple files at once.
In the next step, you will choose how you want the processed images saved.
Step 3: choose a destination image format
PhotoDemon needs to know which format to use when saving the images in your batch list.

If "keep images in their original format" is selected, PhotoDemon will attempt to save each image in its original format. If the original format is not supported, a standard format (JPEG or PNG, depending on color depth) will be used.

If you choose to save images to a new format, please make sure the format you have selected is appropriate for all images in your list. (For example, images with transparency should be saved to a format that supports transparency!)
In the final step, you will choose how you want the saved files to be named.
Step 4: provide a destination folder and any renaming options
In this final step, PhotoDemon needs to know where to save the processed images, and what name to give the new files.
For your convenience, a number of standard renaming options are also provided. Note that all items under "additional rename options" are optional.

Finally, if two or more images in the batch list have the same filename, and the "original filenames" option is selected, such files will automatically be given unique filenames upon saving (e.g. "original-filename (2)").
Step 5: wait for batch processing to finish
Once the batch processor has processed several images, it will display an estimated time remaining.

You can cancel batch processing at any time by pressing the "Cancel" button in the bottom-right corner. If you choose to cancel, any processed images will still be present in the output folder, so you may need to remove them manually.
Save the current list of images
You haven't selected any image files. Please add one or more files to the batch list before saving.

GIF images only support simple transparency, meaning each pixel in a GIF image must be fully transparent or fully opaque. If your batch list includes 32bpp images with complex alpha channels, PhotoDemon must simplify them before saving to GIF format.
By default, transparency will be split down the middle, or you can specify a custom cut-off value.
Super compression, very poor image quality (256:1)
advanced settings require the FreeImage plugin
Optimization is highly recommended. This option allows the JPEG encoder to compute an optimal Huffman coding table for the file. It does not affect image quality - only file size.
Embedded thumbnails increase file size, but they help previews of the image appear more quickly in other software (e.g. Windows Explorer).

Progressive encoding is sometimes used for JPEG files that will be used on the Internet. It saves the image in three steps, which can be used to gradually fade-in the image on a slow Internet connection.
default settings - CCITT Group 4 for 1bpp, LZW for all others
PKZIP DEFLATE (also known as zLib DEFLATE)
Bitmap files only support one type of compression, and they only support it for certain color depths. PhotoDemon can apply simple RLE compression when saving 8bpp images.
TGA files only support one type of compression. PhotoDemon can apply simple RLE compression when saving TGA images.
TIFFs support both RGB and CMYK color spaces. RGB is used by default, but if a TIFF file is going to be used in printed document, CMYK is sometimes required.
TIFFs support a variety of compression techniques. Some of these techniques are limited to specific color depths, so make sure you pick one that matches the images you plan on saving.
PNG interlacing is similar to "progressive scan" on JPEGs. Interlacing slightly increases file size, but an interlaced image can "fade-in" while it downloads.
PNG files can contain a background color parameter. This takes up extra space in the file, so feel free to disable it if you don't need background colors.
Binary encoding of PPM files is strongly suggested. (In other words, don't change this setting unless you are certain that ASCII encoding is what you want. :)
if PhotoDemon does not support an image's original format, a standard format will be used
( specifically, JPEG at 92% quality for photographs, and lossless PNG for non-photographs )

Waiting for user to specify JPEG export options

PhotoDemon can automatically choose a JPEG quality setting for you. The statistical analyses it uses are designed around photographs; synthetic images or images with large regions of solid color may not work as well.
Perceptive color matching uses the CIE L*a*b* color space for highly accurate color modeling. Enabling this setting may increase processing time by several seconds.
preserve all relevant metadata, but remove personal tags
preserve all relevant metadata, but remove personal tags (GPS coords, serial #'s, etc)
You can change the program-wide setting from the Tools -> Options menu.

Image metadata is extra data placed in an image file by a camera or photo software. This data can include things like the make and model of the camera, the GPS coordinates where a photo was taken, or many other items. To view an image's metadata, use the Image -> Metadata menu.
JPEG previews require the FreeImage plugin.
Super compression, very poor image quality (20)

Waiting for user to specify WebP export options

To enable support for this feature, please copy the FreeImage.dll file into the plug-in directory and reload the program.
All metadata information is supplied by the ExifTool plugin. You can learn more about ExifTool at http://www.sno.phy.queensu.ca/~phil/exiftool/
Click to change the color used for empty borders
when changing aspect ratio, fit image to new size by
fitting inclusively, with transparent borders as necessary
fitting inclusively, with colored borders as necessary
fitting exclusively, and cropping as necessary
Resampling affects the quality of a resized image. For a good summary of resampling techniques, visit the Image Resampling article on Wikipedia.
By default, descriptive names are used in place of technical ones. Advanced users can toggle this option to expose more resampling techniques.
When changing an image's aspect ratio, undesirable stretching may occur. PhotoDemon can avoid this by using empty borders or cropping instead.
adjust size to fit rotated image
keep image at its present size
Arbitrary rotation requires the FreeImage plugin, which could not be located. Rotation canceled.
The FreeImage plugin is required for image rotation. Please go to Tools -> Options -> Updates and allow PhotoDemon to download core plugins. Then restart the program.
Note: this operation will flatten the image before tiling it.
the new image will be %1 %3 wide by %2 %3 tall

This option will create a blank image. Other ways to create new images can be found in the File -> Import menu.
Another way to open images is dragging them from your desktop or Windows Explorer and dropping them onto PhotoDemon.
Open one or more images for editing
If the current image has not been saved, you will receive a prompt to save it before it closes.
Because you have turned off save prompts (via Edit -> Preferences), you WILL NOT receive a prompt to save this image before it closes.
WARNING: this will overwrite the current image file. To save to a different file, use the "Save As" button.
You have specified "safe" save mode, which means that each save will create a new file with an auto-incremented filename.

Use this to quickly save a lossless copy of the current image. The lossless copy will be saved in PDI format, in the image's current folder, using the current filename (plus an auto-incremented number, as necessary).
The Save As command always raises a dialog, so you can specify a new file name, folder, and/or image format for the current image.
Save As (export to new format or filename)
ignore transparent pixels when auto-activating layers
Make current layer transforms (size, angle, and shear) permanent. This action is never required, but if viewport rendering is sluggish, it may improve performance.
Reset horizontal layer shear to zero
Reset vertical layer shear to zero
Make quick-fix adjustments permanent. This action is never required, but if viewport rendering is sluggish and many quick-fix adjustments are active, it may improve performance.
Click to change the way selections are rendered onto the image canvas. This has no bearing on selection contents - only the way they appear while editing.
This option controls how smoothly a selection blends with its surroundings.
These options control the area affected by a selection. The selection can be modified on-canvas while any of these settings are active. For more advanced selection adjustments, use the Select menu.
This option adjusts the width of the selection border.
This feathering slider allows for immediate feathering adjustments. For performance reasons, it is limited to small radii. For larger feathering radii, please use the Select -> Feathering menu.
This option adjusts the roundness of a rectangular selection's corners.
This option adjusts the width of a line selection.
This option adjusts the curvature, if any, of a polygon selection's sides.
This option increases the smoothness of a hand-drawn lasso selection.
Tolerance controls how similar two pixels must be before adding them to a magic wand selection.
The magic wand can operate on the entire image, or just the active layer.

Normally, the magic wand will spread out from the target pixel, adding neighboring pixels to the selection as it goes. You can alternatively set it to search the entire image, without regards for continuity.
This option controls which criteria the magic wand uses to determine whether a pixel should be added to the current selection.
This layer is a typography layer. To edit it with the basic text tool, you must first convert it to a basic text layer.
Click here to convert this layer to a basic text layer.
This layer is a basic text layer. To edit it with the typography tool, you must first convert it to a typography layer.
Click here to convert this layer to a typography layer.

Language file could not be loaded
This tool allows you to create and edit PhotoDemon language files.

Please start by selecting a base language file. If the selected file already contains translation data, you will be able to edit any existing translations, as well as add translations that may be missing.
This page also allows you to delete unused language files. Note that there is no Undo when deleting language files, so please be careful!
Upon clicking Next, the selected file will automatically be validated and parsed. Depending on the number of translations present, this process may take a few seconds.
(For best results, do not use this editor in the IDE!)
In this step, please provide a bit of metadata regarding this language. This information helps PhotoDemon know how to handle this language file.
The most important items on this page are the language ID and language name. If these items are missing or invalid, PhotoDemon won't be able to use the language file.

If multiple translators have worked on this language file, please separate their names with commas. If this language file is based on an existing language file, please include the original author's name.
(NOTE: changes made to this page won't be auto-saved unless you click the Next or Previous button.)
This final step allows you to edit existing translations, and add missing ones.
Every time a phrase is modified, an autosave will automatically be created in PhotoDemon's user language folder. This means you can exit the program at any time without losing your work.
When you are done translating, you may use the Save and Exit button to save your work to a file of your choosing. (Note that autosave data will be preserved either way.)
When you are finished editing this language, please consider sharing it! Contact me by visiting
so we can discuss adding your translation to the official list of supported languages. Even partial translations are helpful!
Please wait while the language file is validated
Validation successful! Loading all phrases and preparing translation engine

This action will reset all preferences to their default values. It cannot be undone.
Are you sure you want to continue?
The image canvas sits "behind" the image on the screen. Dark colors are generally preferable, as they help the image stand out while you work on it.
Click to change the image window background color
Image windows tend to be large, so feel free to display each image's full location in the image window title bars.

High-resolution tracking allows PhotoDemon to more accurately reproduce mouse and pen movement. On some older PCs, the system may struggle to keep up with the extra tracking data, so you can disable this if necessary.
The "Recent Files" menu width is limited by Windows. To prevent this menu from overflowing, PhotoDemon can display image names only instead of full image locations.

This option allows PhotoDemon to scan incoming images to determine the most appropriate color depth on a case-by-case basis (rather than relying on the source image file's color depth, which may have been chosen arbitrarily).
feature disabled due to missing plugin
HDR and RAW images contain more colors than PC screens can physically display. Before displaying such images, a tone mapping operation must be applied to the original image data.

Most digital photos include rotation instructions (EXIF orientation metadata), which PhotoDemon will use to automatically rotate photos. Some older smartphones and cameras may not write these instructions correctly, so if your photos are being imported sideways or upside-down, you can try disabling the auto-rotate feature.
Any photo larger than 2 megapixels is too big to fit on an average computer monitor. PhotoDemon can automatically zoom out on large photographs so that the entire image is viewable.
to match the image file's original color depth
by asking me what color depth I want to use
Some image file types support multiple color depths. PhotoDemon's developers suggest letting the software choose the best color depth for you, unless you have reason to choose otherwise.
the current file format of the image being saved
the last image format I used in the "Save As" screen

Most photo editors use the format of the current image as the default in the "Save As" screen. When working with RAW images that will eventually be saved to JPEG, it is useful to have PhotoDemon remember that - hence the "last used" option.
save a new copy, e.g. "filename (2).jpg" (safe behavior)

In most photo editors, the "Save" command saves the image over its original version, erasing that copy forever. PhotoDemon provides a "safer" option, where each save results in a new copy of the file.
Some image file types support additional parameters when importing and exporting. By default, PhotoDemon will manage these for you, but you can specify different parameters if necessary.
Like any photo editor, PhotoDemon frequently converts colors between different reference spaces. The accuracy of these conversions can be limited to improve performance.
Some interface elements receive custom decorations (like drop shadows). On older PCs, these decorations can be suspended for a small performance boost.
PhotoDemon has to generate a lot of thumbnail images, especially when images contain multiple layers. The quality of these thumbnails can be lowered in order to improve performance.

Rendering the primary image canvas is a common bottleneck for PhotoDemon's performance. The automatic setting is recommended, but for older PCs, you can manually select the Maximize Performance option to sacrifice quality for raw performance.

By default, PhotoDemon's undo data is not compressed. This makes undo operations very fast, but increases disk space usage. Compressing undo data will reduce disk space usage, at some cost to performance. (Note that undo data is erased when PhotoDemon exits, so this setting only affects disk space usage while PhotoDemon is running.)

This setting is the best choice for most users. If you have no idea what color management is, use this setting. If you have correctly configured a display profile via the Windows Control Panel, also use this setting.
To configure custom color profiles on a per-monitor basis, please use this setting.
Please specify a color profile for each monitor currently attached to the system. Note that the text in parentheses is the display adapter driving the named monitor.
Click this button to bring up a "browse for color profile" dialog.
If an image has transparent areas, a checkerboard is typically displayed "behind" the image. This box lets you change the checkerboard's colors.
Click to change the first checkerboard background color for alpha channels
Click to change the second checkerboard background color for alpha channels
If an image has transparent areas, a checkerboard is typically displayed "behind" the image. This box lets you change the checkerboard's size.

Because PhotoDemon is a portable application, it can only check for updates when the program is running. By default, PhotoDemon will check for updates whenever the program is launched, but you can reduce this frequency if desired.

One of the best ways to support PhotoDemon is to help test new releases. By default, PhotoDemon will suggest both stable and beta releases, but the truly adventurous can also try developer releases. (Developer releases give you immediate access to the latest program enhancements, but you might encounter some bugs.)

PhotoDemon's volunteer translators regularly update the program's language files. PhotoDemon can automatically download these updates separate from the main program, ensuring that you always have the most up-to-date language files.

PhotoDemon uses some 3rd-party plugins. Sometimes, the authors of these plugins fix bugs or add new features. Instead of waiting for the next PhotoDemon release, you can receive plugin updates as soon as they become available.
PhotoDemon can notify you when it's ready to apply an update. This allows you to use the updated version immediately.

The developers of PhotoDemon take privacy very seriously, so no information - statistical or otherwise - is uploaded during the update process. Updates simply involve downloading several small XML files from photodemon.org. These files contain the latest software, plugin, and language version numbers. If updated versions are found, and user preferences allow, the updated files are then downloaded and patched automatically.
If you still choose to disable updates, don't forget to visit photodemon.org from time to time to check for new versions.
Copy the report to the system clipboard
max PhotoDemon memory usage this session
NOTE: options on this page have been disabled because the FreeImage plugin could not be located.
NOTE: Many of these file format options require the FreeImage plugin. Because you do not have the FreeImage plugin installed, these options may not perform as expected.
Interface options include settings for the main PhotoDemon interface, including things like canvas settings, font selection, and positioning.
Load options allow you to customize the way image files enter the application.
Save options allow you to customize the way image files leave the application.
File format options control how PhotoDemon handles certain types of images.
Performance options allow you to control whether PhotoDemon emphasizes speed or quality when performing certain tasks.
Color and transparency options include settings for color management (ICC profiles), and alpha channel handling.
Update options control how frequently PhotoDemon checks for updated versions, and how it handles the download of missing plugins.
Advanced options can be safely ignored by regular users. Testers and developers may, however, find these settings useful.
WARNING: this folder is invalid (access prohibited). Please provide a valid folder. If no new folder is provided, PhotoDemon will use the system's default temp location.
